body:
I am sure others can fill in more but here is a sketch of our decision to not use The XDG spec.
- XDG focuses on Linux, but ipython runs everywhere.
- Consistency within ipython is more important than platform specific specs. We tried using the XDG spec for a while and all it did was confuse users moving between platforms
- XDG has not been adopted universally even on Linux. Your characterization that only things created in the 1970s aren't adopting XDG isn't accurate.
- Ipython's usage of .ipython is not new - it goes back to 2001
- IIRC The XDG spec fragments an applications data across multiple directories in a way that is difficult to reconcile with ipython's profiles

Sent from my iPhone

> On Aug 3, 2014, at 10:54 AM, Alex notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> We really shouldn't be considering dumping crap in the user's home directory in 2014.
> 
> The XDG Base Directory Specification, which is followed by most programs today, specifies that user-specific data files should be stored in ~/.local/share, user-specific configuration files should be in ~/.config, and user-specific nonessential cache files should be in ~/.cache.
> 
> Git uses ~/.config/git, GTK uses ~/.config/gtk-2.0, even chromium does this. There are a few hardcoded disappointments such as .ssh, .pki, and .bashrc, which only really do so due to historical baggage. But exploiting a Unix bug to "hide" all sorts of crap in $HOME really shouldn't be done today.
> 
> You wouldn't treat /, /usr, and /usr/local the same way. But it's sad when a project, tabula rasa, with no 1970's historical baggage, opts for using "dotfiles" in the user's home.
> 
> ~/.ipython is an inappropriate location for user-specific data, and should be moved to ~/.local/share/ipython or ~/.config/ipython.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

Easy enough:
- The XDG directories `.config`, `.cache`, and `.local` apply to OS X and BSD as well. Not necessarily for windows, but `~/.*` isn't standard either. And I'm sure most people could tolerate `~/.local/share/ipython` on OS X, windows, and linux.
- Storing data directly in the home directory and not in the OS-designated location (XDG, `~/Library`, `~/AppData`, etc) is considered poor form. I'd argue that every application that does it is wrong, not just according to the spec, but using the basic namespacing argument.
- Surely IPython doesn't have the downstream dependencies of bash or ssh or fontconfig? Informing dependents of an upcoming breaking change should be possible.
- And at minimum the spec merely separates cache and persistent data, a reasonable request similar to OS X's `~/Library/Caches` vs `~/Library/Application Data`.

Thanks for the proposition, 

A little more background as Brian was probably a little short in his explanation. 
As you liked to the XDG specification, you probably that moving `~/.ipython/` to `~/.local/share/ipython` or `~/.config/ipython`would not make it less "crap" as per the XDG definition of what should be in the different directory. The way IPython configuration works does not even fit into the categorization of the XDG spec.

Linux support of xdg across distribution varies wildly, and it is **not** to upstream to add distribution specific logic to do "the right thing" on each distribution. As your research of XDG on IPython repo would have shown you, the subject has already be treated many times and trying to follow `.config/crap` pattern was more pain both for developers and user that we thought, and not right. 

You compare us to project that have huge amount of funding and/or developer to adopt xdg, and are also younger. So if you can provide us with the manpower and/or funding to achieved the transition to something that suit the spec that would be nice. This mean : 
- developer time to go through the code base and code the different case, 
  - support 13+ years of legacy user
  - add hooks for linux distro to decide whether or not use `.config`
  - security audit to be sure files places in these dir are not accessible as they contain temporary credential to connect to kernels) 
- special case non-linux that do not follow XDG
- developer time that write docs. Please also do not make the doc too complicated. But you can probably find a way to explain to user that if they are on mac, it's `.ipython`, on window , well I don't even know, and linux, it depends on wether you install with `pip` or distrib package. 
- You might want also some time to respond to complaints, bug report. And also someone to fix all the post on the internet that link to `~/.ipython`

As a benevolent working only on my free time on IPython, I don't have enough time to work on that, and probably not the expertise. 

We would likely help the packager to have IPython use XDG,  if you find an easy way, please "just" make a Pull Request, we will be happy to review.

---

> The XDG directories .config, .cache, and .local apply to OS X and BSD as well.

Apparently `git` at least disagree with you.

Let's try to keep the tone polite here and focused on the technical issues.

Just as a data point, on my open-source embracing Mac, there are 35
dotfiles/dotdirs in my home directory (ignoring things like bash and ssh)
and only 3 in .config.

Just to reinforce what others have said, we did roughly follow XDG for a while, by putting the IPython directory in `~/.config/ipython` on Linux and BSD. We decided to return to `.ipython` for two main reasons:
1. When we describe to users where to look for config files, and things, in docs and in support requests, it's much clearer if we can just refer to one default location, which is the same across all platforms. Cross platform consistency is more important to us than following three different sets of platform specific conventions.
2. We weren't properly following the XDG spec anyway. Our IPython directory combines things that XDG would split up into config, application data and runtime. Separating those out is a bigger task, leading to additional complexity and maintenance, without much reward.

If you personally want to go back to using `~/.config/ipython`, you can achieve it by setting the IPYTHONDIR environment variable to that path.

Feel free to continue the discussion here, but I'm closing the issue because I don't think we intend to do anything about it.
